segments.text: This is very capable, dynamic personality.
How did he treat his men?
Well, there's some people in Texas that thought he didn't treat us very well.
That was at the Rapido River.
And that's on up the way, you know, to Salerno.
Because they thought that his order across the Rapido River was an ill-conceived plan.
Of course, he was the Army commander.
There's a Corps commander between him.
And how much the Corps commander is responsible for, it's nothing.
But it's easy when he was unsuccessful to say it wasn't a very good plan.
MacArthur's plan, going an inch on it, wasn't a very good plan either.
But he was highly successful.
So he becomes a brilliant individual.
And I'd say Clark was brilliant.
popular with the troops.
Of course, it's long distance from an Army commander and a troop.
They'll only see who's out and landed in that plane, and they say, well, that's General Clark, or if he's out in the formation.
Like where I got to keep in the Silver Storm, me, the entire division was in formation.
We were out of the lines.
But they were way back, and we all marched up, you know, lined up in front.
But as we went up the Rapido River,
What made that so questionable was that it wasn't a surprise night attack, because they had already been probing along the way.
And instead of making a frontal attack across the river in the valley, we would do the way I would teach it.
You would say it's best to take the high ground.
and then come back behind rather than trying to frontally attack, assault, fortified positions.
But now why did he do it?
Because we had the first armored division in Italy.
And people said, well, why do you have an armored division in the mountains of Italy?
Well, somebody's got to answer that question.
They say, well, there's some broad valleys in Italy that you can let armor go right on up there and overrun, get on up to Rome to get this thing over with.
So they weren't looking for high ground to penetrate.
They were looking for level ground to utilize the armor.
So that was the reason why we attacked down there where we did.
It had heavy casualties.
And it was ordered to attack again.
This is daytime now.
Actually, it was unsuccessful on the first time.
They attacked again.
They had even more heavy casualties.
Then they ordered to attack the third time.
And I said, we just don't have the people.
We've lost leaders, and we've got wounded hanging on the wire on the other side, calling for help, you know, many.
So I decided not to attack.
Well, there was so many Texans in the 36th Division, you know, they immediately went after Clark's scout.
And they got politics involved with it here.
And it cost him.
He never did.
He wasn't selected as chief of staff.
or the Army, which he thought he was going to be because of that Rapido River.
I think it's a little unfair to Clark as a Corps commander, maybe, but it was unfortunate.
And the thing about the 36th, that was the second, see, first for the battalion.
The rest of the division didn't suffer so much in here.
in Salerno, but here you had the division.
It really took a beating on that.
Would you say that at Rapido there was almost a mutiny from the American troops?
Well, they said they weren't going to attack a third time.
No, the leaders said that.
So the leaders said that we just don't have, in general, we just don't have the troops to continue this.
That's right.
So that leader was relieved.
Oh, was he?
Yeah.
That's Colonel Martin, the one that welcomed me on the train with open arms.
But wasn't he just telling the truth?
Yeah, but then they tried to investigate it and said that lack of leadership because of the negative attitude
You know, if you start sympathizing with the troops and telling how bad it is, and you're one who should know, they'll say, boy, that's right.
But if you say, you may say, well, that's not being truthful.
You may say, well, things are not as bad as you think they are.
Because it's just like, I often think, back there was a baseball umpire
I can't call his name now.
He's written a lot of books, too.
And he says, his picture's through this ball, you know.
And one says it's the ball, and the other says it's a strike, you know, depending on which team he's supporting.
And he says, there ain't nothing till I call it.
And that's right.
It's a missile through the air until he puts a name, nomenclature on it.
And it's only a stripe because he said so or not.
And they said, well, if you don't believe you're out, he said, read the morning's paper and you'll find out the statistics of the game that you're out.
In many situations, particularly in combat, it can be worse than you think it is.
It can not be near as bad.
But you tend to perceive it in different ways, you know.
Now, the role of a leader is to keep a cool head, and you'll find that you're not near as bad as you think it is, or you perceive it to be, or it appears to be.
And I think that's the difference between a successful and an unsuccessful.
Now, we'll go through this whole entire narrative, but of course you're not going through a whole World War II.
But we've actually had leaders.
I had one to me, the finest officer that I think that...
And this was another battle after Rapido, which I was gnawed on in this next one coming up at Monte Cassino.
I was a... Why don't you just spread that out?
Well, after Rapido... Oh, by the way, the same time we attacked Rapido to get the Army Division across,
The 24th Division attacked the high ground above Cassino, above Monte Cassino, and they were successful.
So, but they didn't have any troops now to exploit that because they were attacked down below and up there, and they only had the two divisions, couldn't get these others.
If there had been a feint down here, and then you put the whole thing through, you know, in the back, and then you go on back behind,
And then you could attack and it was uncovered.
In fact, you'd have them pinned.
They'd have to pull back.
Now it's true that you go back and that's hindsight.
So 24th was successful, but nothing to do to exploit.
They didn't have sufficient forces then to continue on because they got down weak.
They'd get chewed up also.
But we could have taken Cassina from the rear at the beginning.
But then we really had heavy carriers.
They had heavy carriers.
Now you've got two divisions decimated.
The third has been in combat.
They're just out trying to get refitted.
And that's the core right there of the three divisions.
So after this one, pulled out of the line, got replacement, trained, and then we took what we had left.
of your men at Rapido.
Yeah.
And we replaced the 24th Division up on the mountain.
I had the battalion in.
I was a major of what was left of the battalion.
By the way, we had a truce with the Germans.
I told you earlier how the Germans cooperated on
relieving the poor, tired Americans and those guards to get their people back and say, if you can do that while we're fighting each other.
At the Rapido, we had a truce.
We asked for it.
Chaplain went down, got permission from the division, division headquarters.
So we went down with the truce.
I went down there with them.
And the Germans permitted us to get the wounded off of the wire across the river
Okay, they bring him back, yeah.
And it was a one-hour truce.
And it was arranged by map on grid square.
You know, at this time there would be no gunfire whatsoever on the grid square.
And they abided by it, and we abided by it.
So you went down and picked your soldiers out?
Yeah.
You sent the medics in?
Yeah.
I personally didn't go.
I was on the river.
Were they pretty beat up?
Oh, the men had wounds?
Yeah, oh, some had terrible wounds.
Others had life wounds.
Some of them were hanging in the wire.
That's what was difficult.
So they had buckets.
The fortifications were beautiful.
The river's not very large, wide.
It was deep because it's rapid at that time of the year.
But the Germans had a sunken road hundreds of years behind, parallel to the river.
The Germans had a tunnel from the sunken road
into the, not underwater, but to the bank.
And they put their machine guns all the way down the river.
And then they had them the other way, coming this way, interlaced, you know, with fire.
So the poorer devils who were attacking, you aren't attacking the gun, it's killing you at all.
You don't even see it, all you know, you're getting hit.
And then they had barbed wire and mines, in other words, it was fortified, to rip up the fence.
And this is what, we got across, we got across with a,
bridges, foot bridges.
So you could get across.
You know, a lot of people got wounded trying to get the bridge installed and also cross it.
But that's the reason why there were people there on the wire.
They couldn't go far and they couldn't go back.
And the Germans weren't going to get out of their fortification to get them out.
So they agreed to it.
How did you even contact them?
They did it by radio.
And a German...
came and talked to me in well-dressed.
He came to talk to you?
Yeah, in English.
He said, and he was telling the truth, he said, you lads certainly don't conduct river crossings like I was taught at Leavenworth.
That's what he said to you?
Yeah, he and our commanding staff called him Leavenworth.
Here he was all clean and, you know, perky little cap on and...
standing there with clean-shined boots and flipping his swagger stick.
And what rank was he?
I don't remember.
I think he was a captain or maybe a major.
I think he wasn't hiring the Lord.
And so you got a hold of these people on the radio, and then you said, well, meet you, let's talk about this.
Yeah, I personally didn't have anything to do with the troop except to participate in it, being down there on the river.
I didn't talk.
I don't know how the chaplain, how he arranged it, but some way that they had it with the Germans.
And there I was.
But that's what the German said to you?
Huh?
But that's what the German said to you when he came over to discuss his troops?
Yeah.
He, too, was just observing like I was, you know.
Of course, he wanted to come on our side because he wanted to get a reconnaissance to see whether we had anything, which we didn't have.
Mm-hmm.
Fortifications or troops all dug in.
Well, when he said that about Leavenworth, what'd you say?
I just shook my head.
That wasn't funny to me.
And he was right.
I would never conduct a river crossing that way.
Surprise, yes.
If you really go slip up there and all, they want you to throw this across without them manning their guns.
They already probed it with reconnaissance.
They knew what it was.
So what they were trying to do, we were trying to do, is just overwhelm them, you know, with bodies.
That's pretty hard to do with machine guns firing at you, mortars and artillery.
In fact, many of our boats were pneumatic, of course, shrapnel or fragments deflated, big ripping, gacking holes in them.
And that's before we ever tried to do it.
So you can see how well anybody said, okay, they're going to try to have it.
Boat parking, wherever it is.
Tell me a little bit more about this scene.
Did the other Germans that they sent over during this truce, did they speak English too?
I don't know.
See, most of the action was on the other side.
I didn't go on the other side.
I stayed on our side.
I went on the other side during the attack and came back.
But what happened during the truce is that they sent this German officer over for one hour to your headquarters, basically?
No.
Well, how did you meet this one?
I'm a little confused.
Okay, the chaplain arranged for this truce.
I know I talk about this, and I just say it.
You say, well, if you can do this, why in the hell are we fighting each other, see?
You know, if it's this simple, let somebody else do it.
The chaplain arranged for it.
And the second truce, which I'll get to later, I have a paper on that, like,
find it somewhere.
It was written up by the Inspector General who was involved in the second one.
I went down to Water's Edge, actually arranged for it.
They came down to the channels, headquartered it, say a truce had been arranged and gave the grid square for this particular time.
So my only job down there was to go down there and just observe on my own, rather than sleeping or trying to get ready to go in a few hours.
The German had no responsibility at all either.
He just came as a sightseer also.
But he couldn't resist seeing me on the other side and with the ponton type of bridge that we had there till across the river.
He came on over there on this side.
But we probably should have done this, captured him when he got over there, even during the truce with him being so cocky.
But he was right.
And that's about all the conversation, because I wasn't going to talk with him.
Why not?
I was too beaten up.
The next truce, I did a lot of talking.

What were your feelings toward when, I mean, were the people, did they have a lot of hatred for the enemy, or were they indifferent during this truce, or did they think it was a humane thing to have this truce?
What did the people feel like?
What did your soldiers and you feel like?
Well, I guess I think it was humane, because we're the ones who asked for it and benefited from it.
I guess that
You had a few troops around.
What do you think about this?
They said, well, I think it's good to get these wounded back and bodies back because they're one of us.
Whether they think this is the proper way to fight a war or not, I don't know.
I don't think probably an infantry officer would have even thought about asking for a troop.
Certainly we don't have any manuals and on certain conditions this is what you do.
You contact the enemy and ask for truce.
That's almost medieval.
Do you remember what the chaplain's name was?
But he instigated this truce.
Yeah.
Along with the Red Cross flag, I mean, they went down.
What a difference between fighting in Europe and fighting in the Orient.
Yeah.
For the Japanese.
But anyway.
The Germans, to give another one, I was talking about Denholm earlier.
Denholm got captured in North Africa.
And they took him and inventoried his money, his pocketbook, and put it in an envelope.
Let him keep his watch.
And treated him just like...
The president of war is supposed to be treated.
He'd treat him as an officer and a gentleman, fed him well.
He later escaped and later on got wounded.
But that's the type of standard that the German Army had because they were very professional, especially that North Africa Corps.
Not many draftees at that time because, see, that was the elite unit that they had.
But then what we had left, we went back on up and relieved the 24th.
And I was in charge in the battalion.
I had about less than 200 men left.
Out of how many?
And now we have a new commanding officer.
This is named Paul D. Adams, who later on got to be a four-star gentleman.
But out of the battalion, I guess we had, at that time, probably
So you lost.
Out of 700, you only had 200 left?
Yeah.
What a casualty rate.
Yeah, you can look at the journals and see it each month.
You know, we listed the people that were killed.
Was morale decreasing because of this tremendous casualty rate?
Yeah, but war... Infantry particularly, you got...
I'm talking about now like in Italy or like in the Far East that they had in those campaigns there, particularly in the islands where Peter went all the time.
He got rocked.
It almost becomes a case of survival.
And you're mad at anybody that's making your life so miserable.
I don't mean you're mad at the president.
I don't care who it is that cross there that's causing you all of this sort of thing.

And you, I don't know why you'd call it hatred, but it's just a, if I'm going to be this miserable and I'm going to have all these casualties, well, I'm going to see that you have it as bad as we are, or worse, hopefully.
Now, France and Germany, it was a different war, you thought.
Yeah.
I'm talking about now where you, gosh, I got trench foot.
in Italy, up in the mountains in the cold, rain season.
And of course it says, change your socks, you don't keep them.
We didn't have any socks.
We changed, everything was wet.
So the time we got out, the peat was kind of shriveled up.
And then we took a hot shower.
And boy, they get about twice the size.
And it was all swollen up.
You can't walk.
And it takes a long time to get over it.
And that's what happened later on.
Now we're up above Cassino, above
and behind at Monaco Center.
Just thinned up there.
We have emplacements, machine guns.
So the Germans mounted a massive attack.
Artillery and mortars, they slammed to us for about an hour.
Well, we dug in and we sustained the attack pretty well.
Then they came.
We put down all our artillery and machine guns on them.
But what really killed them was
that their artillery wasn't clearing the mask of the hill.
It wasn't coming up and coming down.
It was slamming into their own troops.
Their own artillery was slamming into their own troops?
Yes.
Wow.
So finally got all quiet, see.
And then daylight finally came.
And I got out there and I started looking, and we had German bodies all over the place.
Wounded Germans.
They could easily overrun us if it hadn't been for that, because once again, they had the truth.
But this is an all-mountain, you know.
So it's not a case of as you climb, you get all up there, and then you get a red detect.
And they didn't realize it because they were firing at night.
Yeah.
So, lo and behold, later that day, the Germans had asked for truth.
Now, this is a different unit, you know, and everything about it is old.
We were in better shape then.
We had very few cavemen.
So we were all dug in, and they never got to the hand-in-hand combat.
So this was arranged.
And this one, because I got to say, I got a piece of paper somewhere.
The inspector general wrote up this one.
So he was up there.
So it must have been a division before they came up.
So the Germans came up to pick up their dead.
So here comes a German.
officer up to who would say he spoke a little broken and different from down there, that this guy here looked more combat like he did.
And he spoke English, and so I told him that I thought that the German artillery was better trained to fall short and kill their own troops.
Don't they teach them better than that in the artillery school?
What did he have to say to that?
He said, I'm afraid you're right.
That's what he said?
I'm afraid you're right?
They realized that all over that they wanted to give us credit, which, of course, is all right.
That's good for your morale, too, if you don't think your own people are.
But that's where the heavy caves were, right down just short.
Before they ever got into our line of fire, before they came up, see?
And they asked for an extension on that because they had a heck of a time, you know, getting those people.
In other words, they needed more than an hour?
Yeah, and it was granted.
But once again, it was a peculiar situation.
And you could hear all the firing going on all around, you see.
It's just quiet around that Monte Cassino area.
So that's my two experiences on truces during the war.
Do you remember what rank this German officer was?
But he looked pretty combat.
He wasn't spit and polish.
Was he arrogant like the first one?
No.
You don't find many arrogant infantry officers in combat.
Especially if they're tired.
Like those cartoons, Willie and Joe.
That cartoon all you can get.
How do you know if he's a fresh troop if you don't wake him up and ask him?
You know, there's two old guys leading on his rifle.
That's a fresh troop.
Well, anyway, we finally went on up to Anzio.
Now, I mention this because this time, the Corps commander, and Clark's still Army commander, takes a recommendation
of General Walker, the commanding general of the 36th.
And it turned out what should have been another bloodbath, like Rapido, turned out to be brilliant.
Anzio, of course, is down in a broad plain that goes along the coast all the way to Rome, but still a lot of mountainous territory around it.
Well, the plain doesn't go all the way to Rome.
There's another group of mountains before you get to Rome.
Anyway, there's some plain.
So we're in the beachhead in the plane.
And because we're under observation all the time, there was a perpetual smoke stream all around the edge of the perimeter.
So the Germans up in the high ground couldn't observe.
And they didn't have air superiority, so they couldn't see very much by plane.
Most of their aircraft operated at night.
And the left receives astride the main artery that comes down through that.
So the plan was 36th Division to attack the left wing and the flaps a little bit below.
Once again, this is a frontal attack on a fortified position.
At least they're well dug in.
So General Walker this time, he went to the corps commander and said, I have a plan I'd like to submit.
And he said, all right, what is it?
So he told his corps commander, he said, well, you know, I can't prove this.
We'll have to go to General Clark and present this because this is counter to what's already been planned.
So they went up to General Clark and they briefed him.
And he says, okay, we'll try it.
What General Walker had done, he had contacted the Italians around there.
And he had been
talking with this engineer about the desirability of finding some way over that mountain other than going head on against the lecture.
And the Italian said, yes.
I know a route that goes over the mountain.
It's just a trail.
Well, the engineer said, well, can it be widened, you say?
He said, well, yes.
How you going to widen it?
He said, we'll take a bulldozer.
We'll get where we can get jeeps and trucks over that area.
So they made a reconnaissance.
And since the Germans were down here, and this mountain rib goes out like this, they were able to get up there.
And they made a reconnaissance.
And they didn't want to go all the way over, because they'd give away the plane.
And the engineer said, sure, he can do that.
That's what they sold General Clark on.
So we made what we call a Chinese attack, where you pull out all the stuff, but really nobody moves anymore.
You have the tanks firing, and even anti-aircraft would be firing.
We did that.
And the Germans bought it.
They thought, well, yeah.
They expected, of course, you're going to break out of that beachhead and try to sooner or later would be great.
And hit them frontal.
But what you're really doing is... Planking them.
Yeah, you're taking the flank.
Yeah.
Up and over the hill.
Yeah.
And they weren't concerned about that because only patrols could go over, and they had troops in the rear to take care of patrols.
Bicycle troops, by the way.
Yeah.
And they got surprised because they came to the rescue, you know, to knock out this patrol.
And lo and behold, they found out they had a two battalion frontal attack against them in the rear.
So while that was all going around, our troop pulled out and went on around to the rear, got to this place.
And of course, the infantry went on up ahead, which my battalion was a
I wasn't the battalion commander in this particular one, but the battalion I was in was leading the attack.
Went on over and got on down.
And sure enough, it was just about daylight.
You didn't see any Germans anywhere around.
So we went on down.
In the meantime, the engineers using bulldozers was widening and scraping and knocking down trees unnecessarily, getting rocks out of the way to where
The first the jeep to get over, and then they kept working and improving it to where a larger truck could.
And by 10 o'clock the next morning, we had not only the infantry down there, but also the supporting weapons, like mortars.
So then we moved on out to cut the road behind Belletri and start Barone.
That was the objective this time.
So we got the entire division, crossed that mountain,
down behind the Germans.
Now the Germans could only pull out, and they couldn't pull back straight.
They had to go not quite parallel with the front line, but behind the others.
And that, since it's a coordinated attack, then they all cut loose, see?
Because after you want to do that, you weaken them, then these others are getting out of position.
It's a British unit.
So the Germans then are...
Not quite surrounded, but about three quarters.
Yeah.
So they're trying to get out toward Rome, but they can't go back on the main road because it's cut.
So they're having to go across, sort of trooping the line in the rear.
And the British unit attack and others is a coordinated attack and is very successful and took a lot of prisoners.
The reason about the bicycle, when we got there, who wasn't coming in, you know, to counterattack with a company on bicycle?
And I went to Rome, and then later on, of course, we went up to pull it out of the line at Pembino.
Well, before we get on that, let's talk for a minute about the British troops.
You worked right with the British troops, and the British general in charge was Alexander at this time.
Did you ever have an opportunity to see Alexander?
Yeah.
I was too low level.
I didn't chat with him.
He talked to us.
How did he strike you?
He came in North Africa.
He came before we went into Italy.
And we didn't have any idea what was going to happen.
We didn't know that we had anything to do with the British troops.
We didn't see anything like that.
And he kind of let the cat out of the bag and he welcomed us to his command.
And, of course, we all looked at each other in amazement.
What is he talking about?
But he's a real fine.
He was basically the Supreme Commander of all the troops.
So he was over Clark.
Now, how did you get?
You thought that he was a real fine officer, but you didn't really get an opportunity to talk to him.
No, I know more about him on a bread than my business.
That's the only time I ever saw him.
OK, now.
Of course, during this time, the British troops were also in the campaign.
Did you have any opportunity to work with the British?
Yeah, in Italy we were Coordinating efforts with them?
And Missoula and also the Gurkhas.
Of course, they were British troops, Commonwealth troops, and the Gurkhas.
And how were they?
Would you make a comment on the quality of these other British troops?
Oh, fine.

had the disadvantage because it galled them because many of their lorries as they called it didn't have four-wheel drive so it all through italy and elsewhere you know you had a lot of bypasses and taking an american vehicle with winches on it the winch on the british and even then a typical british
They rationalize it, saying, well, you bloody Americans, you don't need four-wheel drive except at certain times.
And so it's inefficient.
We sell them every four-wheel drive, so why have it on all your vehicles?
So we say, so we wouldn't have to be wedging you through this pipeline.
You're holding up our troops.
Is there a pretty good department?
And the New Zealand troops are really outstanding, too.
Well-trained.
They couldn't understand why they took them away from New Zealand and Australia and Australia.

And then we turn around and send American units in New Zealand and Australia, particularly Australia, because they get letters from home, you know, about all of their girlfriends and sisters and so forth that's going with these Yankees.
All the young men in their country's gone.
So the same thing in Great Britain, of course.
We had that big contingent waiting for the invasion.
Of course, the British had all their troops around the world.
But there was never any, as far as you can remember, there was no animosity between the Americans and the British Commonwealth?
Not to my knowledge.
Just good cooperation.
I'll tell you a story that really has nothing to do with this.
like you can even cut the machine off, you know, about British-American relationship.

You know, when we were preparing for the invasion, I wasn't in Great Britain at that time, in England, but we had all these troops, and we had horses, and in one area there, they had a series of messes, since you had officers billeted all around, you know, in different buildings, but they had, I guess it was in Hyde Park, that big park,
where they had all these messes lined up like this.
And this officer, and Eisenhower especially emphasized he wanted a good relationship with our allies, great British since we're in their country, we're their guests.
But he doesn't want our troops to go British, you know, to get speaking their language, all that stuff.
But be yourself.
But be, make sure you're friendly.
And this officer right now, I can't,
think his name, Mimi could help me because his son was with us up at West Point.
He had been drinking in the middle of the day, so he was in this mess.
And he got in an argument with a British officer about some subject like I just told you about, you know, four-wheel drive.
Anyway, something in comparison to the military.
And he was loud and
They got in an argument, and finally the friend that was with him, American officer, got him out of the Army and laid him out.
And said, you should not have done that.
My God, a gentleman out there would go hear about this, and you would be on the first ship pulling.
You disgraced yourself and your nation by being so loud, boisterous, uncouth.
And he said, you were right.

i'm going back and apologize oh no let's don't do that he says i insist i you're right so he went into the mess and this time of course it's all buzzing you know they're eating like that he called for attention though let me have your attention it took quite a while to get them calm quiet and down so he says i want you to know that i made an ass out of myself i've disgraced my
nation, and I apologize, and I hope you will accept my apology.
And he was just so quiet and old, looking at him like, what in the hell is going on?
He had gone into the wrong mess.
He'd gone into another mess.
He said, that really happened.
Of course, I never heard about this.
Obviously, that was the talk of the clubs.
I bet you the British got in charge of that.
When you went up into Rome, what were the conditions in that city like?
Well, it was good because Rome had been an open city.
There wasn't any damage.
And the bridges were all intact because they're beautiful bridges, works of art.
And, of course, Rome was really welcome.
You could barely get the vehicles through the street.
Because, I say, America was popular, at least then, all through Italy.
In fact, to go back,
In Italy, you remember here recently they had those terrible earthquakes where it found one of those villages I had been in and entertained it.
When those people got captured between the Salerno and Colorado River, two officers that was captured, the Germans loaded them on a train that was heading north.
And of course, they threatened them.
If anybody tries to escape, we'll shoot all of them.
But they saw an opportunity during the night to jump off the train while it was moving.
Of course, it wasn't going very fast.
And they escaped.
They went up the mountain to this village in the Italian.
And they're really poor people.
They're villages because they work the vineyards and everything.
They live together, but they really have nothing.
They make their own wine, and they have chicken with eggs.
And you know that they give most of their eggs and chickens to the Catholic Church, to the Padres, who really live very nicely.
So they took these two officers and hid them.
They put them in a potato bin off of the .
And of course, the German patrol came around looking for them and threatened to kill all Italians.
And they said, we don't know anybody in America.
And they didn't find them.
And then they would send up food for them to eat and water.
And they stayed hidden for several days.
And about, I guess, two weeks later, we moved on up.
And then they could rejoin the crew.
Well, later on, I had never been there.
Later on, Quarles, that's his name.
He's a Colonel Reserve officer.
He's a very prominent lawyer in Florida, Miami.
The other officer was later killed.
He said, since we're out of the line, we've got a few days, would you like to go with me back up to the village for these people who helped me?
Had me hit and all this time.
So I said, yeah.
So we got some things from the kitchen that they could spare.
We got
chocolate candies, things that other people had that they could let us out.
And he would load it up the Jeep with all that sort of stuff.
And went up into that mountain.
Very difficult to get even in the Jeep because it goes way up.
Most people just walk.
And when they saw him, they all turned up.
Oh, and they're singing and dancing and they brought out their wine and he handed that out to them and they cried and they embraced him.
But the sad part of the story is that was the village that was one of the villages that they had all those caves.
Just put way up in the mountain.
And the buildings, oh gosh, they're several hundred years old.
In fact, sometimes it's old you think that they had been ravaged by gunfire or something, you know, because some were cracking and falling off.

During this time, there was a lot of discussion between Roosevelt, Churchill, and American and British military commanders about not invading southern France, but invading through Austria and through the Alps and the so-called soft underbelly of Europe, which of course George Marshall thought was absolutely out of the question.
Was any of this discussed down on the lines?
Never.
When did you hear about this?
Later?
Too low rank later on.
Too low.
I'm not even sure that some of the very senior people knew about that discussion.
I didn't know until after the war that we made this landing in Africa or reinforced it.
as evidence that we were doing something.
But as you say, Churchill said, all that's wasted evidence because the future, post-war, will be most important.
Because he saw the danger of communism, or USSR, I should say.
He hadn't even gotten away from communism himself.
That that would be the threat.
Was he looking for a way to defeat Hitler, and at the same time, profit by, to better stabilize, at least not the world, at least the Western position.
But I don't think all that battle in North Africa was for naught, because it gave us a first victory for the Allies.
And it turns out now that it is.
But for a while it looked like he was really on the track.
Of course, Tito didn't break away, but he came almost neutral, at least because he was so closely tied to the USSR.
When did you first learn about
Operation Anvil, the invasion of southern France, which took place in June 1944.
We were up, as I said, in Piovino, which is getting up in the extreme north of Italy.
And we were pulled out and went all the way back to Naples.
And then, of course, we knew that we were getting ready to go somewhere because delighted to get out of Italy.
Why?
Because of the terrain and the weather, not because of the time.
You know what it is to live like an animal for all winter, living in a home and eating.
I got where the eating those K rations they call them.
I don't know whether you remember those things.
I don't know if you've seen them.
This had these

canned egg and old crackers that taste like because they had lemon crystals and lemon crystals you couldn't mix with water in other words it was a packaged ration that was really unsuccessful it might have been all right but eat it two or three days but the cheese i got to wear that i couldn't keep anything down no i'm kidding the food was so bad that you were vomiting all the time you had this problem with the feet it had come back back up now
The reason we weren't eating sea rations is because they were heavier.
See, we didn't have helicopters there.
We were supplied by mules.
No kidding.
And you couldn't even supply a lot of arms.
You couldn't get trucks up to you?
Oh, no.
We were up on top of those mountains.
We were supplied by mules up at Monte Cassino, up where that attack occurred.
You couldn't get vehicles.
Well, you couldn't even get them halfway.
There was a village halfway up, a small village, but they had just a winding walk type of thing.
And mules make good pack animals, but horses, you know, horses love them.
Because a horse, well first a mule's just smarter than a horse, more intelligent.
Whether it's innate intelligence or what it is.
